newsitem.title: USA: Jury selection to start in Fla. Medicaid case.
newsitem.headline: Jury selection to start in Fla. Medicaid case.

text.p: Jury selection was set to begin Friday morning in Florida's billion-dollar lawsuit seeking to force tobacco companies to pay the cost of treating sick smokers.
The case is the first of the state's so-called "Medicaid suits" against the industry to make it to trial.
Florida Gov. Lawton Chiles and Attorney General Bob Butterworth both attended the opening session.

"This is the first time the American public is going to find out the full truth about what the tobacco companies have been doing, what they've been hiding for the past 40 years," Butterworth said on the steps of the Palm Beach County Courthouse.
Some 300 jurors were assembled from which attorneys will select a panel of six jurors and nine alternates to hear the state's 1995 lawsuit against major cigarette makers.
In the suit, Florida aims to force the tobacco industry to repay the costs for Medicaid treatment of thousands of Floridians allegedly harmed by tobacco smoke.
As the first of 40 similar state lawsuits brought against the industry to go to trial, the case is being carefully watched by legal scholars and financial markets.

But with a $368.5 billion global settlement under discussion in Washington, there is a chance that the lawsuit will not be resolved in court. Congress may approve the global pact, rendering the lawsuit moot, or Florida could settle, as did Mississippi.
Like many past lawsuits against the industry, Florida's lawsuit claims tobacco companies made a dangerous and defective product and misled the public about its risks.

But the lawsuit differs dramatically in one respect. Where past actions were brought by smokers or family members who said they were directly hurt by cigarettes, Florida is a third party, unaffected by smoke and seeking only to recover costs.
